title: The Heather-Moon
author: Williamson, C. N. (Charles Norris)
snippet: "I thought,"he said, "that I was a humble reincarnation of Thomas Ecildoune--Thomasthe Rhymer--and that I was walking in the Rhymer's Glen--it isn't farout of this neighbourhood, you know--when a Vision in a magic motor-carcame sprinting down the steep curve of a rainbow.

title: The Heather-Moon
author: Williamson, C. N. (Charles Norris)

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _April_ 12.--We breakfasted with the Fergusons, after which Anne andMiss Erskine walked up the Rhymer's Glen.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We drove to Chiefswood, and fromthat to Janeswood, up the Rhymer's Glen, and so home.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: My walk to-day was up the Rhymer's Glen with Skene.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: When I came home I walked through the Rhymer's Glen, and I thought howthe little fall would look if it were heightened.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Walked up the Rhymer's Glen with John Richardson.[31]

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I showed him the plantations, going first round theterrace, then to the lake, then came down by the Rhymer's Glen, and tookcarriage at Huntly Burn, almost the grand tour, only we did not walkfrom Huntly Burn.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Walked with Hugh Scott up the Rhymer's Glen, and round by thelake.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _April_ 7.--Made out my morning's task; at one drove to Chiefswood, andwalked home by the Rhymer's Glen, Mar's Lee, and Haxell-Cleugh.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We wentthrough all the Terrace, the Roman Planting,[108] over by the Stiel andHaxellcleuch, and so by the Rhymer's Glen to Chiefswood,[109] which gavemy heart a twinge, so disconsolate it seemed.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: But indeed Tom alwaystalked of _our buiks_ as if they had been as regular products of thesoil as _our aits_ and _our birks_.[82] Having threaded, first theHaxelcleugh, and then the Rhymer's Glen, we arrived at Huntly Burn,where the hospitality of the kind _Weird-Sisters_, as Scott called theMiss Fergusons, reanimated our exhausted Bibliopoles, and gave themcourage to extend their walk a little further down the same famousbrook.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: But indeed Tom alwaystalked of _our buiks_ as if they had been as regular products of thesoil as _our aits_ and _our birks_.[82] Having threaded, first theHaxelcleugh, and then the Rhymer's Glen, we arrived at Huntly Burn,where the hospitality of the kind _Weird-Sisters_, as Scott called theMiss Fergusons, reanimated our exhausted Bibliopoles, and gave themcourage to extend their walk a little further down the same famousbrook.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Huntly Burn, a mountain brook from which the house was named, finds its way from Cauldshiels Loch through the Rhymer's Glen, " famous in tradition as the scene of Thomas the Rhymer's interviews with the Queen of Fairy."

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: AVe went through all the Terrace, the Roman Planting,' over by the Stiel and Haxellcleuch, and so by the Rhymer's Glen to Chiefswood,' which gave my heart a twinge, so disconsolate it seemed.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I showed him the plantations, going first round the terrace, then to the lake, then came down by the Rhymer's Glen, and took carriage at Huntly Burn, almost the grand tour, only we did not walk from Huntly Burn.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Having threaded, first the Hexilcleugh, and then the Rhymer's Glen, we arrived at Huntly Burn, where the hospitality of the kind Weird- Sisters, as Scott called the Miss Fergussons, reanimated our exhausted Bibliopoles, and gave them courage to extend their walk r little further down the same famous brook.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: A., has recentl) painted a full-length portrait, with the scenery of the Rhymer's Glen ; and his familiarity with Scott renders this almost as valuable as if he had sat for it.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: — We breakfasted with the Fergussons; after which Anne and Miss Erskine walked up the Rhymer's Glen.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: We went through all the Terrace, the Roman Planting,* over by the Stiel and Haxellcleuch, and so by the Rhymer's Glen to Chiefswood, which gave my heart a twinge, so disconsolate it seemed.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Well, but I was much pleased with all I saw, and particularly with the high order Mr. Bayley has put everything  into ; and I climbed Bennarty like a wild goat, and Bcrambled through the old crags like a wild-cat, and pranced through your pastures like a wild-buck (fat enough to be in season though), and squattered through your drains like a wild-duck, and had nearly lost myself in your morasses like the ninth legion, and visited the old castle, which is not a stupit place, and in short, wandered from Dan to Beersheba, and tired myself as effectually in your dominions as I did you in mine upon a certain walk to the Rhymer's Glen.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: I know it's near the burn ; though this fool of a map marks that as running through the Rhymer's Glen.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: The linked sweetness of the Rhymer's Glen is long drawn out ; and no words of mine can bring before the eye the beauty that it wears.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Walked with Hugh Scott up the Rhymer's Glen, and round by the lake.

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: It was the scene ofa fierce clan fight between Scott's ancestors and theDouglasses; it was hard by Melrose, and close toHuntley Bank and the Rhymer's Glen, where Thomasof Ercildoun met the fairy queen.
